title: Former Worcester councilor found guilty of assault on police officer related to ICE arrest
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Etel Haxhiaj, former Worcester councilor, found guilty of assaulting police officer during an ICE-related arrest.
Haxhiaj sentenced to six months probation; acquitted of interfering with a police officer in the same incident.
Incident occurred during May 2025 ICE arrest; sparked protests and criticism at Worcester City Council meeting.

title: JetBlue lounge at Logan Airport will make its debut this summer
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: JetBlue's BlueHouse BOS lounge will open at Logan Airport's Terminal C near gate C23 this summer.
The Logan lounge, nearly 11,000 sq ft, will be 40% larger than JetBlue's JFK lounge.
Amenities include complimentary food, a full-service bar, private workspaces with free WiFi, and uniquely Boston features.

title: ESPN predicts Patriots will target offensive lineman with 1st-round pick in 2026 NFL Draft
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: ESPN predicts Patriots will select offensive tackle Caleb Lomu with their first-round pick in the 2026 NFL Draft.
Caleb Lomu, a 6-foot-6, 304-pound lineman from Utah, is noted for not allowing a single sack in 2025.
Patriots coach Mike Vrabel supports current left tackle Will Campbell despite postseason struggles in Super Bowl LX.

title: New Red Sox Caleb Durbin models his game after former Boston MVP
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Caleb Durbin has been added to the Boston Red Sox roster following a six-player trade with the Milwaukee Brewers.
Durbin, who admires and models his game after Dustin Pedroia, is known for his strong defense and low strikeout rate.
The infielder aims to enhance his power at Fenway after hitting 11 home runs and a .387 slugging percentage in 2025.

title: Jaylen Brown offers Drake Maye advice on how to ‘level up’ after  championship heartbreak
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Jaylen Brown advises Patriots QB Drake Maye to use Super Bowl loss as motivation to improve.
Brown shares personal experiences of overcoming NBA Finals and conference final defeats through self-belief.
Brown emphasizes emotional resilience and suggests focusing on personal growth and positive affirmation.

title: Mass. spa owner, manager arrested on prostitution charges
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Westborough Wellness Spa owner Michael Langille and manager Leir Guo arrested on prostitution-related charges after February 10 investigation.
Investigation initiated following a man's cardiac arrest at the spa; spa lacked required permits for body massages.
Police evidence included online ads for sexual services and testimonies from clients receiving such services at the spa.

title: NFL insider: Patriots ‘will be’ 1 of the teams interested in trading for Maxx Crosby
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots are interested in trading for Raiders edge rusher Maxx Crosby, who recorded 10 sacks in 2025.
Crosby's relationship with the Raiders is strained due to a management decision to sit him out in 2025.
Crosby reportedly wants to play for a Mike-Vrabel-coached team, making the Patriots a potential fit.

title: Cyclists clear snow from Comm. Ave. bike lanes after storm, call on city for accountability
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Cyclists and volunteers cleared snow from Commonwealth Avenue bike lanes, highlighting delays in city snow removal efforts.
Boston Cyclists Union and BU Urbanism Club seek city accountability for maintaining winter bike lane accessibility.
City removed 92,000 cubic yards of snow, issued 3,626 violations, sparking concerns about snow handling in bike lanes.

title: 7 things to do this Valentine’s Day weekend
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Enjoy winter-themed activities at Boston Frostival including a Ferris wheel and silent headphone movie at Copley Square.
Try new Asian restaurants like Novo Lantern, Boxfish, and K-Bok, or attend the Lunar New Year Festival Gala.
Participate in free ice skating events at Canal District Kendall and Boston Common Frog Pond with free rentals and refreshments.

title: City’s police oversight agency is finally starting to subpoena Boston cops
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Boston's Office of Police Accountability and Transparency has subpoenaed nine police officers amid concerns about officer cooperation.
This marks the first time OPAT exercised its subpoena power granted by the 2021 ordinance establishing the agency.
Subpoenaed officers' appearances are linked to seven cases set for a closed-door session during OPAT's upcoming meeting.
